title: Chiquito (actor)
text:
Augusto Valdes Pangan, Sr. (March 12, 1932 – July 2, 1997), professionally known as Chiquito, was a <a href="Philippines">Filipino</a> actor and comedian.
Biography.
Chiquito was born Augusto Valdes Pangan, Sr., in <a href="Manila">Manila</a>. His entertainment career began at the age of 13, when he appeared in a major musical production at the <a href="Manila%20Grand%20Opera%20House">Manila Grand Opera House</a>. In the next several years, he was a fixture in the Manila <a href="bodabil">bodabil</a> circuit, popular for his skill in dancing the <a href="boogie-woogie">boogie-woogie</a>.
Chiquito was befriended by <a href="Fernando%20Poe%2C%20Sr.">Fernando Poe, Sr.</a>, and with Poe's assistance, started a film career. He broke into films with "Sanggano" from Palaris Pictures. He would star in over a hundred films, mostly comedies, over the next five decades. He established his own production company, Sotang Bastos Productions, named after his favorite film role from the 1950s. He would ride on the crest of ever popular comedy spoofs of <a href="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> genres such as the <a href="crime%20film">gangster film</a> and the <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a>. 
In one of these Western spoofs, "<a href="The%20Arizona%20Kid%20%281971%20film%29">The Arizona Kid</a>" (1971), he co-starred with Hollywood <a href="sex%20symbol">sex symbol</a> <a href="Mamie%20Van%20Doren">Mamie Van Doren</a>. Chiquito portrayed the very first male version of <a href="Darna">Darna</a> in the film "Terebol Dobol", preceding <a href="Dolphy">Dolphy</a>, who only later came out with his own "portrayal" of the superheroine in "<a href="Darna%2C%20Kuno%3F">Darna, Kuno?</a>".
In 1984, Chiquito was nominated for a <a href="FAMAS%20award">FAMAS Best Supporting Actor</a> Award for his role in "<a href="Lovingly%20Yours%2C%20Helen">Lovingly Yours, Helen</a>", a film dramatization of the radio and <a href="GMA%20Network">GMA</a> television show hosted by <a href="Helen%20Vela">Helen Vela</a>. 
Chiquito also entered into local politics. He was elected three times as member of the local council of <a href="Makati">Makati</a>, serving from 1969–72, 1988–92, and from 1995 until his death. He served a brief stint as Vice-Mayor of Makati. In <a href="1992%20Philippine%20general%20election">1992</a>, Chiquito made an unsuccessful bid to the <a href="Senate%20of%20the%20Philippines">Senate</a> of the <a href="9th%20Congress%20of%20the%20Philippines">9th Congress</a>.
In 1994, Chiquito made a brief showbiz comeback when he teamed up with rapper-comedian <a href="Andrew%20E.">Andrew E.</a> in the movie ""Pinagbiyak na Bunga" (Lookalayk)" under Viva Films. The movie was a big success and later on had a television spin-off that same year entitled "Puno't Bunga" aired over <a href="GMA%20Network">GMA Network</a>. He later had supporting roles in movies like ""Ang Pagbabalik ni Pedro Penduko" (opposite Janno Gibbs), "Bangers"" (with <a href="Joey%20de%20Leon">Joey de Leon</a> and Andrew E.), and "Strict ang Parents Ko" (with Amanda Page).
Personal life.
He was survived by his widow, Vilma Isidro-Pangan. The couple had seven children.
Death.
Chiquito died at age 65 due to <a href="Hepatocellular%20carcinoma">liver cancer</a> at the Makati Medical Center on July 2, 1997. Philippine media called the day of his death "the day the laughter died".
Accolades.
In 1984, Chiquito was nominated for a <a href="FAMAS%20Award%20for%20Best%20Supporting%20Actor">FAMAS Award for Best Supporting Actor</a> for his role in "Lovingly Yours, Helen", a film dramatization of the radio and GMA television show hosted by Helen Vela.
